results.title: The Way of a river
results.brief_description: This film follows the River Test, Hampshire, from its source to its mouth in Southampton Water. It is a clear, swift-flowing trout stream, completely unmpolluted, despite factories on its lower reaches. Underwater sequences of trout spawning and a fish’s eyeview of the angler are shown.
results.description: This film follows the River Test, Hampshire, from its source to its mouth in Southampton Water. results.title: The Way it is
results.creator_credit: Diane Beaudry, ONF | NFB and Beverly Shaffer
results.brief_description: This sensitive drama examines the effects of divorce on a family, particularly on a twelve-year-old girl. Although Helen Murray’s parents were divorced two years ago, Helen still hopes for a reconciliation. When a visit from her father is cancelled, an emotionally charged confrontation with her mother takes place. Helen admits her anguish over the divorce and realizes that she must learn to accept the situation. An excellent film for both children and adults on the themes of family communications and coping positively with family break-up, The Way It Is can be used for discussion in family-life courses and single-parent groups, and for individual and couples counselling. Cast: Stephanie Daniel, Anick Farris, Kevin Riley, Ronna Sinclair, Shauna Wilkie

results.title: The Way I see it
results.creator_credit: Leon S. Gold, Roundtable Productions and Jack Denove
results.brief_description: A case study which explores the effect of perceptual differences on supervisor-subordinate relations and on job performance. Looking critically and objectively at both sides the roots of the differences are seen as perceptual. The problem is not resolved.

results.title: The Waters of Coweeta
results.creator_credit: United States. Forest Service and Dick Mosher
results.brief_description: Shows the result of twenty years of research work at the hydrologic laboratory on the Coweeta Experimental Forest in the Natahala Mountains of North Carolina. Illustrates the experiments conducted to define more exactly the damage to water supplies and soil. This was done by creating the conditions of unplanned hillside farming, woodlands grazing, and indiscriminate logging.

results.title: The Water waster
results.brief_description: A humorous look at the very serious problem of water wastage that poses the question “Can a water waster really be cured?” Steve Blackburn (of Tim and Debbie fame) plays the part of an irresponsible water user who needs to be taught a lesson or two.

results.title: The Water trolley (K)
results.creator_credit: Penny Spence, Nine Network and Noel Price
results.brief_description: When young Paul’s father is badly hurt in an explosion, his mother calls in the Flying Doctor Service and Paul is left to care for the farm. His immediate concern is to fetch water from a nearby property - a task that becomes fraught with difficulties. Based on a story by Colin Thiele.

results.title: The Water trolley
results.creator_credit: Penny Spence, Nine Network (Australia) and Noel Price
results.brief_description: When Paul’s father is badly hurt, the Royal Flying Doctor service has to be called. Paul is left in charge of the farm and must fetch water from a nearby property. This becomes a task fraught with problems. Based on the novel by Colin Thiele, this is an excellent production from the makers of the award winning children’s dramas, “Danny’s egg” and “Banduk”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Penny Spence, Nine Network (Australia) and Noel Price

results.title: The Water of life
results.creator_credit: Tom Williamson and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Big ice: views of Antarctica”.
The Antarctic continent is a unique natural laboratory for the study of simple life forms, and of physical and behavioural adaptations to inhospitable surroundings. The ocean surrounding Antarctica also has the world’s greatest untrapped food supply. The film asks whether controlled exploitation and development can take place without upsetting the delicate balance of nature.

results.title: The Water must go somewhere
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton, Roan Hannam and Graham Chase
results.brief_description: Illustrates the advance-warning techniques associated with flooding. Also shows methods of evacuation, and consequences of not following evacuation orders. Gives some criticism of the practice of building in areas where flooding is inevitable. Uses actual film footage shot during floods in Richmond, New South Wales.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Malcolm Otton, Roan Hannam and Graham Chase
